text: a controversial extradition bill which
sparked month of violent protests in
Hong Kong has been formally withdrawn
the legislation would have allowed
criminal suspects to be extradited to
mainland China mass demonstrations
against the bill sparked a wider
pro-democracy movement that has spiraled
of course into the worst crisis for Hong
Kong since he was handed back by Britain
to China more than 20 years ago let's
get more on this and talk to our
correspondent Jonathan Haidt he joins me
live now from Hong Kong
John Jonathan we knew that this bill was
going to be withdrawn will its formal
withdrawal make any difference to
protesters do you think no very little a
timing of course is everything had this
been withdrawn perhaps four months ago
it might have made a very big difference
back then that was the spark that set
off the protests but of course there
were very large numbers of underlying
grievances which have really come to the
fore the five demands as the protest
movement describes it including
crucially what they want is a full
universal suffrage are fully elected
assembly and leadership for Hong Kong so
their demands had gone well beyond it in
a way you know it was a bit of a damp
squib this this withdraw it was
announced back at the beginning of last
month by chief executive Carrie Lam
after she'd already described it earlier
as dead the former withdrawal takes it
completely off the books it happened in
a fairly low-key session at the
Legislative Council there was a little
bit of shouting towards the government
from opposition lawmakers but apart from
that they got it done very quickly but
frankly the protest movement has moved
beyond that people we've spoken to say
too little too late we need to see a
great deal more andesite from this there
really hasn't been much of a response
from the Hong Kong government right
through this crisis they've pleaded for
people to go back off off the streets
they've announced a series of packages
to help the economy which has been very
badly affected but nothing that
addresses the political demands of a
protest movement that has shown
extraordinary tenacity and even now we
had very serious clashes over the
weekend very large-scale protests as
well and rallies there's no sign that
it's going to stop there's no
sign the government will change its tack
there's no sign that the police will
stop their attempts to to block the
protesters it's almost like a kind of
drama that just goes on and on and on so
in a way you know Hong Kong has have
seen this extradition bill go shrug
their shoulders and brace themselves
probably for more trouble to come
meanwhile Jonathan the formal withdrawal
of this extradition bill comes on the
same day that the case which sparked the
extradition bill in the first place
the man involved in that has actually
voluntarily returned to Taiwan just
explain more about that to us well in a
way that's another another issue that's
almost been forgotten at the time the
extradition bill was introduced of
course the big issue for Hong Kong was
was the the fear that they would be able
to be extradited to China where they say
they don't face fair judicial
proceedings but Carrie Lam had cited the
case of this 20 year old man who is
wanted for murder in Taiwan he's a Hong
Kong national and he was actually
released today having served a sentence
here in Hong Kong for money laundering
but there's actually been a tussle
between Hong Kong and Taiwan about
whether he goes back and how he goes
back frankly we've all got a bit lost in
to why that's going on it seems there is
now an agreement that he goes back to
Taiwan he's willing to go back he
doesn't mind that he will face murder
charges back there but again you know
while this was cited a great deal at the
very beginning of this crisis earlier
this year I think for many Hong Kong was
that spark has almost been forgotten in
the much wider political demands and
sense of disillusionment among Hong Kong
was over the way in which this territory
is governed okay Jonathan had in Hong
Kong thank you for the update
